<article xmlns:xlink=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"" xmlns:mml=""http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"" article-type=""retraction""><?properties open_access?><front><journal-meta><journal-id journal-id-type=""nlm-ta"">Indian J Dermatol</journal-id><journal-id journal-id-type=""iso-abbrev"">Indian J Dermatol</journal-id><journal-id journal-id-type=""publisher-id"">IJD</journal-id><journal-title-group><journal-title>Indian Journal of Dermatology</journal-title></journal-title-group><issn pub-type=""ppub"">0019-5154</issn><issn pub-type=""epub"">1998-3611</issn><publisher><publisher-name>Medknow Publications & Media Pvt Ltd</publisher-name><publisher-loc>India</publisher-loc></publisher></journal-meta><article-meta><article-id pub-id-type=""pmid"">25483454</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""pmc"">4248516</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""publisher-id"">IJD-59-629</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""doi"">10.4103/0019-5154.143618</article-id><article-categories><subj-group subj-group-type=""heading""><subject>Retraction</subject></subj-group></article-categories><title-group><article-title>Serum Mucosa-Associated Epithelial Chemokine in Atopic Dermatitis: A Specific Marker for Severity: Retraction</article-title></title-group><pub-date pub-type=""ppub""><season>Nov-Dec</season><year>2014</year></pub-date><volume>59</volume><issue>6</issue><fpage>629</fpage><lpage>629</lpage><permissions><copyright-statement>Copyright: © Indian Journal of Dermatology</copyright-statement><copyright-year>2014</copyright-year><license license-type=""open-access"" xlink:href=""http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0""><license-p>This is an open-access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-Share Alike 3.0 Unported
column5:
provided the original work is properly cited.Serum mucosa-associated epithelial chemokine in atopic dermatitis: a specific marker for severity

The following article is hereby retracted from the journal with immediate effect:

MH Ezzat
column6:
KY Shaheen. Serum mucosa-associated epithelial chemokine in atopic dermatitis: a specific marker for severity. Indian J Dermatol. 2009 Jul;54(3):229-36. doi: 10.4103/0019-5154.55630. (http://www.e-ijd.org/text.asp?2009/54/3/229/55630).[1]

This decision is reached based on communication from an alert reader
column7: a report of a fact finding committee appointed by the editorial board of Indian Journal of Dermatology
column8:
and in consultation with the journal Ombudsman on the charges of duplicate and simultaneous submission of an article published in International Journal of Dermatology in 2009:

Ezzat MH
column10:
Shaheen KY. Serum mucosa-associated epithelial chemokine (MEC/CCL28) in atopic dermatitis: a specific marker for severity. Int J Dermatol. 2009 Aug;48(8):822-9. doi:10.1111/j.1365-4632.2009.04069.x. (http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-4632.2009.04069.x/abstract).[2]

It was further found that the same article was previously published in 2005 in Egyptian Journal of Pediatric Allergy and Immunology:

Ezzat MH
column11:
Shaheen KY. Serum mucosa-associated epithelial chemokine (MEC/CCL28) in atopic dermatitis: a specific marker for severity. Egypt J Pediatr Allergy Immunol 2005;3(2):64-74 (http://www.jespai.org/cms/upload/1393125132.pdf).[3]

The authors were initially served with a show-cause notice and then the dean of the university was also informed when the authors did not respond.

After waiting for another 4 weeks
column12: based on a unanimous decision by the Editorial Board
column13:
a complete restriction on the part of the journal on all future articles in which they are assigned/mentioned as an author/coauthor was imposed and the author was notified accordingly.

The above article is being retracted from the Indian Journal of Dermatology and the authors are barred from submitting manuscript(s) to IJD in future.

IJD maintains a strict principle of absolute zero tolerance in matters like these.

Editor

Indian Journal of Dermatology

column9:
provided the original work is properly cited.Outcome of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in locally advanced breast cancer: A tertiary care centre experience

The article
column10: “Outcome of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in locally advanced breast cancer: A tertiary care centre experience” published in page 215-20
column12:

column10:

column5:
as long as the author is credited and the new creations are licensed under the identical terms.Surgical reconstruction or prosthetic rehabilitation following orbital exenteration: The clinician's dilemma

The article titled
column6: “Surgical reconstruction or prosthetic rehabilitation following orbital exenteration: The clinician's dilemma” published in pages 146-47
column8: vol. 47 of “Indian Journal of Plastic Surgery”[<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] is being retracted. It has been reported and found that the article contains identifiable image of the patient in concern and the same has been used without her permission. Therefore
column9:
in regards of the privacy of the patient and on grounds of infringement of obtaining patient consent the article in concern is being retracted. The patient image will also be removed from the online version of the article.

Editor in Chief

Indian Journal of Plastic Surgery

Int J Mol Med 35: 1369–1373
column5:
2015; DOI: 110.3892/ijmm.2015.2147

Following the publication of this article
column6: an interested reader drew to our attention that Figs. 3B and 4B contained histological data which had previously been published in Figs. 3B and 4B
column8: of the following article: Wiggins JF
column13: Brown D and Bader AG: Development of a lung cancer therapeutic based on the tumor suppressor microRNA-34. Cancer Res. 15: 5923–5930
column14:
2010.

We have tried to contact the authors of the above paper on several occasions for comment
column15: but without success; therefore
column16:
the Editorial Board of the International Journal of Molecular Medicine has taken the decision to retract this publication. We thank the reader for drawing this matter to our attention.

"

Int J Mol Med 37: 1139–1145
column5:
2016.

Following the publication of this article
column6: it was brought to our attention that five of the Figures contained in this study were published entirely
column9: on which several of us were co-authors: Han S
column13: Chen Y and Wang YC: microRNA-218 inhibits oxygen-induced retinal neovascularization via reducing the expression of roundabout 1. Chin Med J (Engl) 129: 709–715
column14:
2016.

While we had intended that these papers offered different research perspectives
column15: we were reminded of the fact that
column16: in submitting the article to <italic>International Journal of Molecular Medicine</italic>
column17: the work described therein was required to be “original research that has not been published previously
column18: and is not under consideration for publication elsewhere
column19: in whole or in part”. Therefore
column20: owing to the redundancy in the data between these publications
column21: the above paper is to be retracted. All the authors have agreed to the retraction. We sincerely apologize for our misunderstanding
column22:
and deeply regret any inconvenience this mistake has caused.

"

We would like to retract the article entitled “Nuclear import of prototype foamy virus transactivator Bel1 is mediated by KPNA1
column7: KPNA6 and KPNA7” published in International Journal of Molecular Medicine 38: 339–406
column8: 2016. The results presented in Fig. 6 have been demonstrated to be unreproducible
column9: and we cannot provide an explanation for this. Furthermore
column10: we have recently identified that the cell cultures used in our experiments were partly contaminated with <italic>Mycoplasma</italic>
column11: which could have contributed to the irreproducibility of the results. In addition
column12: we are currently in dispute with a colleague who has contributed towards this study
column13: but does not wish to be included as a named author on the paper. We are therefore going to retract this article. All the authors unanimously agree to the retraction of this paper
column14:
and we deeply apologize to readers and editors for any inconvenience caused by this retraction.

"

The above named article is to be retracted from the Irish Journal of Medical Science. As a result of poor communication
column13: the manuscript was submitted to<italic> Neuroradiology</italic> whilst still under consideration by the<italic> Irish Journal of Medical Science</italic>
column14: and subsequently published online by<italic> Neuroradiology</italic> on 26th May 2009. The article was published online within the<italic> Irish Journal of Medical Science</italic> on 20th August 2009; due to being the latter of the two article versions
column15:
we have decided to retract the article.

Readers wishing to access the article content can do so at Neuroradiology
column16: August 2009

column4: and build upon the work non commercially
column5:
as long as the author is credited and the new creations are licensed under the identical terms.Case report and clinical databased research study on malaria

The article titled
column6: “Case Report and clinical databased research study on Malaria” published in pages 18-21
column8:
vol. 1 of “Journal of Advanced Pharmaceutical Technology & Research”[1] is being retracted.

It has been reported that there is a conflict between the authors due to concerns raised during the recent studies carried out by the authors on same topics. In the recent studies
column9: the results obtained are not reproducible and there are significant difference in the most of results and final conclusion. This creates number of disputes between authors. So
column10: panel of authors have decided internally to withdraw the article
column11:
as the presented findings are not validated with time and may misguide scientific community.

Editor

Journal of Advanced Pharmaceutical Technology & Research

REFERENCETrivediNDTrivediUNBhandariAPatelMMUpadhyayNCase report and clinical databased research study on malariaJ Adv Pharm Technol Res20101182122247827"

The article titled
column7: “Intrathecal Sufentanil Versus Fentanyl for Lower Limb Surgeries - A Randomized Controlled Trial” published in pages 67-73
column10: Journal of Anaesthesiology Clinical Pharmacology[<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] is being retracted. It has found that the article was previously published in the same journal in pages 507-513
column12:
vol. 26 of Journal of Anaesthesiology Clinical Pharmacology.[2] Technical errors resulted in duplicity of publication. Hence the concerned article is being retracted.

Dr. Anju Grewal

Editor in Chief

Journal of Anaesthesiology Clinical Pharmacology

Retraction: Physical and degradation properties of PLGA scaffolds fabricated by salt fusion technique.The paper entitled “Physical and degradation properties of PLGA scaffolds fabricated by salt fusion technique. J Biomed Res 27(4)
column2: 318–325 (<bold>DOI</bold>: 10.7555/JBR.27.20130001)” has been retracted. The paper is withdrawn at the request of the editor as it contains plagiarized materials from Murphy
column4:
et al. “Salt fusion: an approach to improve pore interconnectivity within tissue engineering scaffolds.” Tissue engineering 8.1 (2002): 43–52. The Publisher apologizes for any inconvenience this may cause.

<article xmlns:xlink=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"" xmlns:mml=""http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"" article-type=""retraction""><?properties open_access?><front><journal-meta><journal-id journal-id-type=""nlm-ta"">J Breast Cancer</journal-id><journal-id journal-id-type=""iso-abbrev"">J Breast Cancer</journal-id><journal-id journal-id-type=""publisher-id"">JBC</journal-id><journal-title-group><journal-title>Journal of Breast Cancer</journal-title></journal-title-group><issn pub-type=""ppub"">1738-6756</issn><issn pub-type=""epub"">2092-9900</issn><publisher><publisher-name>Korean Breast Cancer Society</publisher-name></publisher></journal-meta><article-meta><article-id pub-id-type=""pmid"">25834618</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""pmc"">4381117</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""doi"">10.4048/jbc.2015.18.1.101</article-id><article-categories><subj-group subj-group-type=""heading""><subject>Retraction</subject></subj-group></article-categories><title-group><article-title>Retraction note to: ""Clinical Significance of the Axillary Arch in Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy""</article-title></title-group><contrib-group><contrib contrib-type=""author""><name><surname>Kil</surname><given-names>Won Ho</given-names></name></contrib><contrib contrib-type=""author""><name><surname>Lee</surname><given-names>Jeong Eon</given-names></name></contrib><contrib contrib-type=""author""><name><surname>Nam</surname><given-names>Seok Jin</given-names></name></contrib></contrib-group><pub-date pub-type=""ppub""><month>3</month><year>2015</year></pub-date><pub-date pub-type=""epub""><day>27</day><month>3</month><year>2015</year></pub-date><volume>18</volume><issue>1</issue><fpage>101</fpage><lpage>101</lpage><permissions><copyright-statement>© 2015 Korean Breast Cancer Society. All rights reserved.</copyright-statement><copyright-year>2015</copyright-year><license license-type=""open-access"" xlink:href=""http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/3.0/""><license-p>This is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial License (<ext-link ext-link-type=""uri"" xlink:href=""http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/3.0/"">http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/3.0/</ext-link>) which permits unrestricted non-commercial use
column4:
provided the original work is properly cited.Clinical Significance of the Axillary Arch in Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy

All authors would like to withdraw the article because they have found a mistake in selecting subjects for this study. Some patients underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy following sentinel lymph node biopsy were selected inadvertently as the study subjects
column5: despite those who underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy should be excluded from this study
column6:
and most of them were also considered as the sentinel lymph node failure group because these patients underwent axillary dissection regardless of the results of sentinel lymph node biopsy.

Although a reanalysis of corrected data still demonstrated higher failure rate of sentinel lymph node biopsy in the patients with axillary arch than in the patients without axillary arch (4.2% vs. 1.2%)
column7: the difference of sentinel lymph node biopsy failure rate between two groups became statistically not significant (<italic>p</italic>=0.076) and as a result
column8:
the original conclusions have been compromised.

We deeply regret the mistake to review the patient's medical records carelessly.

The following authors agreed with this retraction decision: Won Ho Kil
column10:
Seok Jin Nam.

This article was retracted on March 31
column11:
2015

The online version of the original article can be found at

http://dx.doi.org/10.4048/jbc.2014.17.3.244

"

column4:
2007. Pages 41–52.

The editors of The Journal of Cell Biology have been notified by Dr. W. Matthew Michael of Harvard University
column5: Cambridge
column7:
that he and the other authors of the article referenced above retract the paper.

The authors state:

It has come to our attention that a mistake was made during the sequencing of the smk-1 allele from the rad-2(mn156) strain that was used in our studies. In our paper
column8: we reported three amino acid substitutions in the protein encoded by the <italic>rad-2(mn156)</italic> allele: E497G
column11: and the correction that was published). We have gone back and resequenced this locus
column12: and we have found that the D to G substitution at position 704 is incorrect
column13: and that instead it occurs at position 928. Thus
column15: E497G
column16: D580G
column17:
and D928G.

This is problematic because we based further experiments on the D704G mutation
column18: most notably an immunoprecipitation experiment which shows that an SMK-1 protein containing the single D704G substitution fails to bind to PPH-4.1 (Fig. 5 C). Because this mutation does not exist in the <italic>rad-2(mn156)</italic> strain
column19: this experiment is now irrelevant. Because this mistake undermines a central conclusion of the paper
column20: that the molecular basis for the <italic>rad-2(mn156)</italic> phenotype is the inability of the mutant SMK-1 protein to bind to PPH-4.1
column21: we are retracting the paper. We note that this sequencing mistake impacts the data reported in Fig. 5
column22: and we have no reason to believe that any of the other data reported in our paper are incorrect or compromised by this mistake. We sincerely apologize for any problems our error may have caused those who were

column2:
The Rockefeller University Press

Reese
column5: dynactin
column6:
and kinesin II's interaction with microtubules is regulated during bidirectional organelle transport. J. Cell Biol. 151:155–166.

Using the methods published in Reese and Haimo (2000)
column7:
the author's laboratory has been unable to reproduce the data in Figs. 2–6 of this article that demonstrate microtubule motor and dynactin regulation as a function of the direction of organelle transport in melanophores. The authors wish to correct the scientific record and retract the findings of this paper until such time as they are able to resolve the discrepancy.

A statement from each of the authors agreeing to the retraction of this article is on file at the Rockefeller University Press.

"

column4:
2005. Pages 903–912.

The editors of The Journal of Cell Biology have been notified by Dr. Gerard C. Grosveld of St. Jude Children's Research Hospital
column5: Memphis
column7:
that he and the other authors of the above article wish to retract the paper.

The authors state:

“Figure 1 of this paper was described as reflecting an experiment that showed that the expression of the FOXO1a protein was downregulated in primary tumor samples of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma patients. In follow-up experiments
column9:
we have shown that the lack of FOXO1a expression reported in Figure 1 is not correct. We are now certain that primary alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma cells do express FOXO1a protein.

Given that the lack of FOXO1a protein in primary tumors was the basis for proposing that FOXO1a acts as a tumor suppressor in this childhood tumor
column10:
we must retract the paper in its entirety.”

"

column1: 0	"""article-type=.retraction"""	"

<article xmlns:xlink=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"" article-type=""retraction""><?properties open_access?><front><journal-meta><journal-id journal-id-type=""nlm-ta"">J Cell Biol</journal-id><journal-title>The Journal of Cell Biology</journal-title><issn pub-type=""ppub"">0021-9525</issn><issn pub-type=""epub"">1540-8140</issn><publisher><publisher-name>The Rockefeller University Press</publisher-name></publisher></journal-meta><article-meta><article-id pub-id-type=""pmid"">15557126</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""pmc"">2172578</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""publisher-id"">1674re1</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""doi"">10.1083/jcb.200208180101804r</article-id><article-categories><subj-group subj-group-type=""heading""><subject>Retractions</subject><subj-group><subject>Retraction</subject></subj-group></subj-group></article-categories><title-group><article-title>Retraction</article-title></title-group><contrib-group><contrib contrib-type=""author""><name><surname>Liu</surname><given-names>Hongjun</given-names></name></contrib><contrib contrib-type=""author""><name><surname>Mardahl-Dumesnil</surname><given-names>Michelle</given-names></name></contrib><contrib contrib-type=""author""><name><surname>Sweeney</surname><given-names>Sean T.</given-names></name></contrib><contrib contrib-type=""author""><name><surname>O'Kane</surname><given-names>Cahir J.</given-names></name></contrib><contrib contrib-type=""author""><name><surname>Bernstein</surname><given-names>Sanford I.</given-names></name></contrib></contrib-group><pub-date pub-type=""ppub""><day>22</day><month>11</month><year>2004</year></pub-date><volume>167</volume><issue>4</issue><fpage>783</fpage><lpage>783</lpage><permissions><copyright-statement>Copyright © 2004
column2:
The Rockefeller University Press

Vol. 160
column5:
2003. Pages 899–908.

The authors retract the above-referenced manuscript on the basis of the fact that one of the major conclusions
column6: regarding the function of paramyosin in myoblast fusion
column7:
is incorrect. The authors stand by all of the other data with the exception of one correction. See below for details.

In this paper
column8: a myoblast fusion defect was attributed to mutation of the <italic>Drosophila melanogaster</italic> paramyosin gene. We now show that the fusion defect instead apparently arises from the <italic>TM3</italic> balancer chromosome. Experiments subsequent to publication using a <italic>TM3</italic>-containing line that lacked a paramyosin mutation suggested that we had mis-identified balancer chromosome–containing individuals before the late embryonic stage as paramyosin mutant homozygotes (<italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup>/<italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup>). By using a lacZ-expressing version of <italic>TM3</italic>
column9: staining experiments unambiguously identified young <italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup> homozygotes and showed them all to lack the fusion defect
column10: implying that the fusion defect is due to the presence of the <italic>TM3</italic> chromosome. We have not tested whether this is a homozygous or heterozygous effect of <italic>TM3</italic>. The apparent rescue of the fusion defect by the wild-type paramyosin transgene is presumably due to the absence of the <italic>TM3</italic> chromosome
column11: instead of the presence of the paramyosin transgene. We conclude that embryos identified as <italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup> homozygotes in Figs. 3 and 4 of the paper
column12: as well as on the cover of the journal
column13: are not of this genotype. We thus retract the conclusion that paramyosin is important for myoblast fusion. In contrast
column14: <italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup>/<italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup> late-stage embryos and larvae were unambiguously identified by mouth hook color
column15:
and so our conclusion regarding myofibril defects in prm1 homozygotes remains valid.

As a result of a PCR artifact and an error in notation
column16: the deletion in the <italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup> allele was stated to be 4 kb in size. Reanalysis of the data as well as additional cloning and sequencing indicate that the deletion is actually 1.05 kb in length and is internal to the <italic>P</italic> element. The deleted region encompasses portions of the upstream region and first exon of the <italic>white</italic><sup>+</sup> gene
column18: the paramyosin coding region itself is not disrupted in either <italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup> or its parent line and both contain a <italic>P</italic> element insert in the transcribed
column19: but not translated
column20: region of <italic>prm</italic> exon 1. Since the normal <italic>prm</italic> transcription start site is upstream of the <italic>P</italic> element
column21: <italic>prm</italic> transcripts likely are produced by transcription from the element into the <italic>prm</italic> coding region or by use of a cryptic transcription start site in the 174 bp between the insertion site and the coding region. Internal deletion of a portion of the <italic>P</italic> element in <italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup> may reduce transcriptional read through or initiation
column22: accounting for reduced expression compared with its parent line. Some internally deleted <italic>P</italic> elements have stronger mutant phenotypes than their undeleted parental element (<xref ref-type=""bibr"" rid=""bib2"">Staveley et al.
column24:
2001).

The authors stand by the data as to the location of the P element disrupting the paramyosin gene (Fig. 1)
column25: the effects of <italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup> and rescue on paramyosin and miniparamyosin expression (Fig. 2)
column26: the expression pattern detected by the anti-paramyosin antibody (Figs. 5 and 6)
column27: the myofibrillar defects found in <italic>prm</italic><sup>1</sup> homozygotes and the rescue of these defects (Figs. 7
column30: the editors require retraction of the entire paper
column31:
and it is consequently marked as such.

The authors sincerely regret these errors and appreciate the opportunity to correct them. We are indebted to Qin Yu
column33: and Jennifer Suggs (San Diego State University
column35:
CA) for their insights and for carrying out the experiments reported here.

column5:
provided the original work is properly cited.A Randomized Controlled Trial to Compare Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannulae with Nasal Continuous Positive Airway Pressure Postextubation in Premature Infants: Retraction

The article “A Randomized Controlled Trial to Compare Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannulae with Nasal Continuous Positive Airway Pressure Postextubation in Premature Infants”[1] that was published in the Journal of Clinical Neonatology | Vol. 2 | Issue 2 | April-June 2013 has been retracted due to a copyright issue raised by the author of the original article in the Journal of Pediatrics.

A revised version of the above article has been published in a previous issue of Journal of Clinical Neonatology | Vol. 3 | Issue 3 | July-September 2014 on page 139 with the title “Heated Humidified High-Flow Nasal Cannulae: A Good Alternative to Nasal Continuous Positive Airway Pressure”.[2]

<article xmlns:ali=""http://www.niso.org/schemas/ali/1.0/"" xmlns:xlink=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"" xmlns:mml=""http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"" article-type=""retraction""><?properties open_access?><front><journal-meta><journal-id journal-id-type=""nlm-ta"">J Conserv Dent</journal-id><journal-id journal-id-type=""iso-abbrev"">J Conserv Dent</journal-id><journal-id journal-id-type=""publisher-id"">JCD</journal-id><journal-title-group><journal-title>Journal of Conservative Dentistry : JCD</journal-title></journal-title-group><issn pub-type=""ppub"">0972-0707</issn><issn pub-type=""epub"">0974-5203</issn><publisher><publisher-name>Medknow Publications & Media Pvt Ltd</publisher-name><publisher-loc>India</publisher-loc></publisher></journal-meta><article-meta><article-id pub-id-type=""pmid"">27099432</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""pmc"">4815554</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""publisher-id"">JCD-19-198</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""doi"">10.4103/0972-0707.178710</article-id><article-categories><subj-group subj-group-type=""heading""><subject>Retraction</subject></subj-group></article-categories><title-group><article-title>Retraction: Role of casein phosphopeptide amorphous calcium phosphate in remineralization of white spot lesions and inhibition of Streptococcus mutans?</article-title></title-group><pub-date pub-type=""ppub""><season>Mar-Apr</season><year>2016</year></pub-date><volume>19</volume><issue>2</issue><fpage>198</fpage><lpage>198</lpage><permissions><copyright-statement>Copyright: © 2016 Journal of Conservative Dentistry</copyright-statement><copyright-year>2016</copyright-year><license license-type=""open-access"" xlink:href=""http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0""><license-p>This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 License
column4: and build upon the work non-commercially
column5:
as long as the author is credited and the new creations are licensed under the identical terms.Role of casein phosphopeptide amorphous calcium phosphate in remineralization of white spot lesions and inhibition of Streptococcus mutans?

The Journal of Conservative Dentistry has decided to retract the article titled
column6: “Role of casein phosphopeptide amorphous calcium phosphate in remineralization of white spot lesions and inhibition of Streptococcus mutans?” authored by Vashisht R
column13: vol. 16 of the Journal of Conservative Dentistry.[<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] Based on the complaint from the editorial office of International Journal of Pediatric Dentistry
column14: it was found that the article is a verbatim copy of an article titled
column15: “Does casein phosphopeptide amorphous calcium phosphate provide remineralization on white spot lesions and inhibition of Streptococcus mutans?” authored by Aykut-Yetkiner A
column16: Kara N
column19: and Ertuğrul F and published in pages 302–306
column20: issue 4
column21:
vol. 38 of Journal of Clinical Pediatric Dentistry.[2]

After a thorough investigation
column22: it is evident that the first author (Dr Ruchi Vashisht) of the concerned article
column23:
[1] was a reviewer of an article[2] by Aykut-Yetkiner et al. that was initially submitted to Int J Paed Dent. This article[2] was rejected by the reviewer(s) in 2012. Dr Ruchi Vashisht later submitted this same article to J Conserv Dent along with a set of coauthors. This article was peer reviewed and was published in our journal in 2013.[1] The original authors (Aykut-Yetkiner et al.) had submitted their manuscript to another journal and got it published in 2014.[2]

The article[1] published in J Conserv Dent has breached the rules of research and publication ethics and constitutes gross research misconduct. The coauthors of this article[1] claim innocence and to be unaware of this. The first author is neither communicating to the journals concerned nor to the coauthors. Therefore
column24:
on grounds of research misconduct the article[1] in concern is being retracted.

Editorial Board

Journal of Conservative Dentistry

editor@jcd.org.in

REFERENCESVashishtRIndiraRRamachandranSKumarASrinivasanMRRole of casein phosphopeptide amorphous calcium phosphate in remineralization of white spot lesions and inhibition of Streptococcus mutans?J Conserv Dent201316342623956538Aykut-YetkinerAKaraNAteşMErsinNErtuğrulFDoes casein phosphopeptid amorphous calcium phosphate provide remineralization on white spot lesions and inhibition of Streptococcus mutans?J Clin Pediatr Dent2014 Summer384302625571679"

2008. Pages 1077–1086.

Following an investigation by officials at the Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center
column6: the editors of the <italic>Journal of Experimental Medicine</italic> hereby retract the article
column7: “Native and aspirin-triggered lipoxins control innate immunity by inducing proteasomal degradation of TRAF6” (2008. <italic>J. Exp. Med.</italic> 205: 1077–1086)
column15: Christopher L. Karp
column16: and Júlio Aliberti. The basis of this retraction is the alteration of data in several panels in Figures 1
column18: and 6. The investigation has determined that D. Hildeman
column19: C.N. Serhan
column20: C.L. Karp
column23:
and A Dias were not involved in any aspect of the creation or manipulation of these figures.

"

column3: A.-R. van der Vuurst de Vries
column5: L.L. Lanier
column7:
and H. Clevers. 2001. The Epithelial Cellular Adhesion Molecule (Ep-CAM) Is a Ligand for the Leukocyte-associated Immunoglobulin-like Receptor (LAIR). J. Exp. Med. 194:107–112.

The editors of The Journal of Experimental Medicine have been notified by Dr. Linde Meyaard of the University Medical Center Utrecht
column9:
that she and the other authors of the above Brief Definitive Report wish to retract the paper.

The authors state:

“Recent studies by our laboratory have revealed that EpCAM is not a ligand for human LAIR-1 and LAIR-2. The prior experiments showing that LAIR-1–hIg and LAIR-2–hIg fusion proteins bind to EpCAM transfectants were an artifact resulting from contamination of the fusion proteins with an anti–human EpCAM monoclonal antibody
column10:
which was affinity purified using the same protein A columns.”

The authors extend their apologies to the scientific community.

"

column5:
2002. Pages 1393–1398.

The Editors of JEM have been asked to print the following retraction
column6:
which was approved by Dr. Larry Pease and by the Mayo Clinic research integrity officer who oversaw the investigation:

An investigation by the Mayo Clinic has determined that one of the researchers in Dr. Larry Pease's laboratory at the Mayo Clinic
column8: tampered with another investigator's experiment with the intent to mislead toward the conclusion that the B7-DCXAb reagent has cell-activating properties. Using blinded protocols
column9: experiments were done to see if published results based on this reagent could be replicated. Specifically
column10: the repeat experiments examined the activation of dendritic cells
column14: breaking tolerance in the RIP-OVA diabetes model
column15: and the reprogramming of Th2 and T regulatory cells. In no case did these repeat studies reveal any evidence that the B7-DCXAb reagent had the previously reported activity. The authors of this paper therefore wish to retract this paper because they were unable to reproduce key aspects of the studies
column16:
and hence the published results cannot be considered reliable.

"

column5:
2002. Pages 1291–1305.

The editors of The Journal of Experimental Medicine have been notified by Dr. Markus Müschen of the University of Cologne
column7:
that he and the other authors of the above article wish to retract the paper.

The authors state:

“In an attempt to repeat the FACS analyses of surface antigens that were described as differentially expressed between naive and memory B cells in our paper
column8: we observed no or only minor differences for most of these molecules. A systematic reanalysis of the primary data in the laboratories of R. Küppers and M. Müschen revealed that incorrect FACS instrument compensations were responsible for the discrepancy (double stainings were performed
column9:
laboratory of M. Müschen).

This prompted us to systematically reanalyze all aspects of our paper. The reanalysis revealed that normalization of SAGE libraries of different sizes had introduced a bias toward larger differences in gene expression between naive and memory B cells when the SAGE tag count was 0 for 1 of the two libraries. In these cases
column10:
differences in mRNA expression identified by SAGE are in reality smaller than reported in the paper and often not significant. Experiments to confirm and extend the main conclusion of our article that B cell receptor signaling is silenced in naive as opposed to memory B cells (laboratories of J. Hescheler and M. Müschen) will be presented elsewhere.”

The authors extend their apologies to the scientific community.

"

column5:
2011. Pages 1485–1499.

At the request of the Dean for Research
column7: the paper “Foxp3-positive macrophages display immunosuppressive properties and promote tumor growth” by Zorro-Manrique
column8:
et al. is now retracted. The Dean states:

“We have recently received requests from readers to clarify the methodology and results in the paper presented by Zorro Manrique and colleagues. Regrettably
column12: and we do not have reliable access to his full methodology and data to substantiate the paper's claims. In our ongoing efforts to respond to reader requests
column13: concerns have arisen that individual methods
column15: labels
column16: and data magnitude may be inaccurately portrayed in the paper. Although the surviving authors maintain a strong conviction that the paper's substance
column17: and the underlying science of regulatory macrophages
column19:
we request the retraction of this manuscript for the reasons stated above.

The reagents provided by co-authors outside of the Mayo Clinic are not implicated in these concerns.

No finding of research misconduct was made concerning the contributions of the surviving authors.”

"

The article titled
column9: vol.5 of Journal of Human Reproductive Sciences[<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] is being retracted. It has been observed that the articles contains several overlapping text sections from a previous published article titled
column10: “A rare cause for primary amenorrhea: Sporadic Perrault syndrome” published in pages 843-845
column12:
vol.16 of Indian Journal of Endocrinology and Metabolism.[2] The authors are the same for both the articles.

Thus on the grounds of duplicity of publication
column13:
the concerned article is being retracted.

Prof. Dr. Debora Weber-Wulff

HTW Berlin

<article xmlns:xlink=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"" xmlns:mml=""http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"" article-type=""retraction""><?properties open_access?><front><journal-meta><journal-id journal-id-type=""nlm-ta"">J Indian Soc Periodontol</journal-id><journal-id journal-id-type=""iso-abbrev"">J Indian Soc Periodontol</journal-id><journal-id journal-id-type=""publisher-id"">JISP</journal-id><journal-title-group><journal-title>Journal of Indian Society of Periodontology</journal-title></journal-title-group><issn pub-type=""ppub"">0972-124X</issn><issn pub-type=""epub"">0975-1580</issn><publisher><publisher-name>Medknow Publications & Media Pvt Ltd</publisher-name><publisher-loc>India</publisher-loc></publisher></journal-meta><article-meta><article-id pub-id-type=""pmid"">25210251</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""pmc"">4158578</article-id><article-id pub-id-type=""publisher-id"">JISP-18-425</article-id><article-categories><subj-group subj-group-type=""heading""><subject>Notice of Retraction</subject></subj-group></article-categories><title-group><article-title>Notice of Retraction</article-title></title-group><pub-date pub-type=""ppub""><season>Jul-Aug</season><year>2014</year></pub-date><volume>18</volume><issue>4</issue><fpage>425</fpage><lpage>425</lpage><permissions><copyright-statement>Copyright: © Journal of Indian Society of Periodontology</copyright-statement><copyright-year>2014</copyright-year><license license-type=""open-access"" xlink:href=""http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0""><license-p>This is an open-access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-Share Alike 3.0 Unported
column5:
provided the original work is properly cited.Reconstructive surgery with chin block graft and esthetic rehabilitation of missing anterior tooth

The lead author of manuscript titled “Reconstructive surgery with chin block graft and esthetic rehabilitation of missing anterior tooth.” J Indian Soc Periodontol 2014;18:263-66 has misrepresented facts and has neither taken adequate permission from nor given due acknowledgement to all authors concerned. Furthermore
column6:
the lead author of this paper has failed to give an adequate explanation and the Editorial Board and Executive Committee of the Indian Society of Periodontology therefore recommend that this paper not be cited as an original piece of work.

To ensure that those credited as authors recognise their role in taking responsibility and being accountable for what is published
column7: the International Committee of Medical Journal Editors (ICMJE) has added a fourth criterion for authorship as part of the new ICMJE Recommendations. The ICMJE now recommends that authorship be based on the following four criteria: (1) substantial contributions to the conception or design of the work; or the acquisition
column9: or interpretation of data for the work; and (2) drafting the work or revising it critically for important intellectual content; and (3) final approval of the version to be published; and (4) agreement to be accountable for all aspects of the work thereby ensuring that questions related to the accuracy or integrity of any part of the work are appropriately investigated and resolved. In addition to being accountable for the parts of the work he or she has done
column10: an author should be able to identify which co-authors are responsible for specific other parts of the work. In addition
column11:
authors should have confidence in the integrity of the contributions of their coauthors.

All those designated as authors should meet all four criteria for authorship
column12:
and all who meet the four criteria should be identified as authors. Those who do not meet all four criteria should be acknowledged.[1]

Authors are reminded that their signature on the contributor's form is the only means of affirming that submission of a manuscript complies with the guidelines of the journal. The review and publication process is seriously undermined when the authors misrepresent compliance with the spirit or letter of the guidelines. The author of the offending paper
column13:
Dr. Preetika Bansal has communicated her apology to Dr. Nymphea Pandit and the editorial office. Author misconduct can never be accepted or defended but the matter is now closed.

Editor - JISP

REFERENCEICMJE

column5:
provided the original work is properly cited.Neutrophil extracellular traps: Their role in periodontal disease

The article
column6: “Neutrophil extracellular traps: Their role in periodontal disease.” published in J Indian Soc Periodontol 2014;18:693-7[<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] is being retracted due to Plagiarism. It has been found that the article contains several sections in the text which have been copied from an earlier article entitled
column7: “Neutrophil extracellular traps as a new paradigm in innate immunity: Friend or foe?” Periodontol 2000 2013; 63:165-97.[<xref rid=""ref2"" ref-type=""bibr"">2</xref>] The lead author of the current paper has failed to give an adequate explanation and the Editorial Board and Executive Committee of the Indian Society of Periodontology therefore recommend that this paper not be cited as an original piece of work and be retracted. The authors of the offending paper have communicated their full
column8:
frank and contrite apology. Hence the article has been retracted.

Dr. Ashish Sham Nichani

Editor
column9:
Journal of Indian Society of Periodontology

It has been brought to the notice of the Editorial Board; Journal of International Oral Health: An Official Publication of International Society of Preventive and Community Dentistry that substantial overlap of study design and significant conflict of interest has occurred involving this study.

The practice was confirmed after due assessment of the contents in the present case and critical evaluation of the claims made by both parties. To condemn such practices in future with special emphasis in regards to original content
column14:
JIOH has decided to retract the published article from the assigned issue.

The Editorial Board
column15:
JIOH shows strict disagreement with such acts and intimates its serious concern for such unethical practices.

"

column5: and reproduction in any medium
column6:
provided the original work is properly cited.Journal of Korean Medical Science 2005; 20: 877-82.

The above article became to belatedly recognized by the editor of Journal of Korean Medical Science (JKMS) having almost same contents with an article which appeared in Korean Journal of Hospice and Palliative Care (=Hankook Hospice Wanhuaeuiryohakhoeji in Korean) 2003;6:152-63
column8: Reliability and Validity of the Evaluation of Korean Cancer Pain Assessment Tool (K-CPAT). The 2003 article was written in Korean language
column9: and authored by Youn Seon Choi
column13: Chang Hwan Yeom and Se Kwon Jang (with corresponding author Dr. J. Lee). Both articles shared same contents of four tables
column14:
appendix and message.

The executive board for publication of the Korean Academy of Medical Sciences discussed the matter on 12 October 2006
column15: concluded that the JKMS article was a duplicate publication
column16: and resolved to retract the article in order to respect copy right of the Korean Society of Hospice and Palliative Care. <italic>Korean Journal of Hospice and Palliative Care</italic> have been indexed neither in PubMed nor in KoreaMed. The corresponding author of the article
column18:
accepted the allegation of the duplicate publication.

column14: Active-Controlled Clinical Trial and Preclinical Animal Study to Compare the Durability
column15:
Efficacy and Safety between Polynucleotide Filler and Hyaluronic Acid Filler in the Correction of Crow's Feet: A New Concept of Regenerative Filler

Editor
column16:
Journal of Korean Medical Science

A reader of the Journal of Korean Medical Science (JKMS) raised concerns regarding the above entitled article violating conflict of interest disclosure (1). The article described the conflict of interest as ""We certify that all authors of this manuscript have had no financial involvement (e.g. employment
column19: stock ownership or options
column20: expert testimony
column21: grants or patents received or pending
column22: and royalties) within the past five years
column23: or will have in the foreseeable future
column24: with any organization or entity with a financial interest in
column25: or financial conflict with
column26: the subject matter or materials discussed in the manuscript.""</italic> The funding record of the article was <italic>""This study was supported by the regional innovation center program of the Ministry of Trade
column27: Industry and Energy at the Skin Biotechnology Center of Kyung Hee University
column30: later reported that the study was a clinical trial of a new filler and the trial expense was supported by a pharmaceutical company which was producing the filler. One of the coauthors
column32: was a researcher in the R&D Center of the company
column33:
and his written affiliation was the company. The corresponding author reported that the coauthor performed the animal experiment but the research integrity was kept unimpaired without any influence by the company's funding and Dr. Kim's involvement.

The executive board for publication of the Korean Academy of Medical Sciences seriously discussed the matter on January 22
column34:
2016. The board concluded that the article was an impaired publication of conflict of interest by wrong disclosure and incorrect notification of funding sponsor. The corresponding author of the article accepted the allegation of the publication board. The editor retracts the above article based on the decision of the board.

PakCSLeeJLeeHJeongJKimEHJeongJChoiHKimBOhSKimIHeoCYA Phase III

column5:
provided the original work is properly cited.Laparoscopic versus open pyleoplasty: comparison of two surgical approaches – a single centre experience of three years

On behalf of the Editorial Team of the Journal of Minimal Access Surgery (JMAS) we regret to announce that the following paper published in the July – September 2008 issue of JMAS is hereby retracted.

Bansal P
column12:
Bera MK Laparoscopic versus open pyleoplasty: comparison of two surgical approaches – a single centre experience of three years. J Min Access Surg 2008;3:76-9.

An identical paper was submitted to the Indian Journal of Surgery whilst it was in peer review with the JMAS and subsequently published in the IJS.

Bansal P

The article entitled “Assessment of intracranial metastases from neuroendocrine tumors/carcinoma” published on pages 435-439
column8: in the Journal of Neurosciences in Rural Practice has been retracted on the request of the author

thermoplasticized gutta-percha and flowable gutta-percha obturation techniques: A comparative in vitro study

The article entitield
column9: thermoplasticized gutta-percha and flowable gutta-percha obturation techniques: A comparative <italic>in vitro</italic> study” published in pages S131-132
column12: 2014 of Journal of Pharmacy and Bioallied Sciences[<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>]
column13:
is being retracted on the charges of Plagiarism.

It has been found that there are several sections in the article that have been copied from an article published in the year 2011 entitled
column14: “Evaluation and comparison of sealing ability of three different obturation techniques — Lateral condensation
column15: Obtura II
column16:
and GuttaFlow: An in vitro study” in Journal of Conservation Dentistry.[2] Sections starting from Abstract till the References have been found to be an exact copy of the previous article.

Editor in Chief

column5:
as long as the author is credited and the new creations are licensed under the identical terms.Combination restoration in full mouth rehabilitation

The article titled
column6: “Combination restoration in full mouth rehabilitation” published in pages S288–S290
column8: Vol. 7 of “Journal of Pharmacy and Bioallied Sciences”[<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] is being retracted. It has been reported and found that the article contains overlapping text sections from another article titled
column9: “Combined Prosthesis with Extracoronal Castable Precision Attachments” previously published in “Case Rep Dent”[<xref rid=""ref2"" ref-type=""bibr"">2</xref>]. The authors have reworded the reference case and have taken text from other sources. Therefore
column10: on the grounds of duplicity of text
column12:
the article in concern is being retracted.

Editor in Chief

Journal of Pharmacy and Bioallied Sciences

column5:
provided the original work is properly cited.Additive effect of propofol and fentanyl precipitating cardiogenic shock

Additive effect of propofol and fentanyl precipitating cardiogenic shock

The manuscript titled “Additive effect of propofol and fentanyl precipitating cardiogenic shock” by Prabhakaran AJ published in Journal of Pharmacology and Pharmacotherapeutics (JPP) 2013;4:217-9.[1] is retracted.

After the publication of the above article
column6: one of the astute readers reported that a large part of the text is plagiarized from a similar clinical description published in Journal of Medical Case Report (JMCR) 2011
column8:
382.[2] Doubts were raised whether the work reported was genuine. We contacted the author who could not satisfactorily respond to our queries but expressed his inability to produce the case records and laboratory reports.

The editors of JPP had a discussion over email and concluded that the JPP article was indeed plagiarized from the JMCR article and the genuineness is suspect. Since the author could not satisfactorily defend his paper and contravened the declaration he made while submitting his manuscript
column9: it was decided to retract the article from JPP and Pubmed and not to consider any manuscript submitted by him in future. The corresponding author of the article Dr. A. J. Prabhakaran
column11: Meenakshi Medical College and Research Institute (Meenakshi University)
column15:
India will be informed of the decision of JPP.

R. Raveendran

Editor-in-Chief

References

PrabhakaranA JAdditive effect of propofol and fentanyl precipitating cardiogenic shockJ Pharmacol Pharmacother20134217923960431GonzálezARMartinez-LuengasILMartínEMBGonzálezSSPichelIAMartinezPALiébanaESMolinaBDCardiogenic shock following administration of propofol and fentanyl in a healthy woman: A case reportJ Med Case Rep2011538221846377"

column5:
as long as the author is credited and the new creations are licensed under the identical terms.Gastrointestinal dysfunction in idiopathic Parkinsonism: A narrative review

It has been brought to attention by the Editor-in-Chief
column6: editorial team and ethical committee of Isfahan University of Medical Sciences that the review article entitled “Gastrointestinal dysfunction in idiopathic Parkinsonism: A narrative review” published in Journal of Research in Medical Sciences
column9: [<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>] has number of unattributed sections of content with high rate of similarity. Duplicate publication violates the editorial policy of Journal of Research in Medical Sciences which follows best practice guidelines given by the International Committee of Medical Journal Editors (ICMJE) and Committee on Publication Ethics (COPE) mentioned on the Information for Authors and as codified in the signed statements made by the authors regarding the copyright of their work. This article has been retracted at the request of the Editor-in-Chief
column10:
Editorial Board and Authors.

Editor-in-Chief

Journal of Research and Medical Sciences

REFERENCESalariMFayyaziEMirmosayyebOGastrointestinal dysfunction in idiopathic Parkinsonism: A narrative reviewJ Res Med Sci20162112628331512"

column5: distribution
column7:
provided the original work is properly cited.The Significance of the J-Curve in Hypertension and Coronary Artery Diseases

Korean Circ J 2011;41:349-53

http://dx.doi.org/10.4070/kcj.2011.41.7.349

On July 31
column9: Korean Circulation Journal (KCJ) published a review article by Park et al.<xref ref-type=""bibr"" rid=""B1"">1)</xref> regarding the J-curve in hypertension and coronary artery diseases. However
column10:
a possibility of plagiarism has been raised in this article.

The Editorial Board of KCJ has examined the review article and has requested the Committee for Publication Ethics of Korean Association of Medical Journal Editors (KAMJE) to provide an adequate conclusion. After thorough investigation
column11:
the Committee for Publication Ethics of KAMJE and the Editorial Board of KCJ have concluded that the article is seriously plagiarizing from an article by Messeri et al.2)

In this regard
column14:
the Executive Committee of the Korean Society of Cardiology has finally decided to retract the article completely. We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused.

I deeply regret to inform you and request for retraction of the case report entitled ""Aortic Dissection and Rupture in a Child"" published in Korean Circulation Journal.1)

This case report was submitted in advance to Journal of Cardiology Cases2) as a case report
column11:
which should have been addressed for the publication in KCJ as duplication.

As the corresponding author
column12:
I will take full responsibility and respectfully request for the retraction of the paper from KCJ.

column8:
provided the original work is properly cited.The Effect of C/EBPalpha or C/EBPepsilon on 32Dcl3 Murine Myeloblasts and #1111 Acute Promyelocytic Leukemic Cells

To the Editor:

I request for the retraction of the article entitled ""The Effect of C/EBPalpha or C/EBPepsilon on 32Dcl3 Murine Myeloblasts and #1111 Acute Promyelocytic Leukemic Cells"" published in the Korean Journal of Laboratory Medicine 2004 Dec;24(6):339-46.

I deeply regret to inform you that I had written this article without the permission of Professor Scott Kogan
column9: with whom I had conducted the reported research at the University of California at San Francisco. Professor Kogan had later published essentially the same work in the article ""Lee YJ
column14:
Kogan SC. CCAAT/enhancer binding proteins alpha and epsilon cooperate with all-trans retinoic acid in therapy but differ in their antileukemic activities. Blood 2006 Oct 1;108(7):2416-9. Epub 2006 Jun 20.""

As the first and corresponding author
column15:
I hereby retract the paper ""Lee YJ and Kogan S. The Effect of C/EBPalpha or C/EBPepsilon on 32Dcl3 Murine Myeloblasts and #1111 Acute Promyelocytic Leukemic Cells. Korean J Lab Med 2004 Dec; 24(6):339-46.""

"

column19:
provided the original work is properly cited.A novel carbamoyloxy arylalkanoyl arylpiperazine compound (SKL-NP) inhibits hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channel currents in rat dorsal root ganglion neuronsTo Editor in Chief

We would like to request a retraction of our paper [1] entitled
column20: ""A novel carbamoyloxy arylalkanoyl arylpiperazine compound (SKL-NP) inhibits hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channel currents in rat dorsal root ganglion neurons"" by Gehoon Chung
column25: Hongsik Moon
column26: Hyun Jin Kim
column27: Joong Soo Kim
column29: from The Korean Journal of Physiology & Pharmacology. Vol 16 (4) 237-241
column30:
2012.

We regret to inform that the published paper included a few parts that disclosed confidential information which should have been protected under patent law. We admit that the request for retraction is due to the indiscretion of the authors
column31:
and confirmed that editorial committee of KJPP have not conducted any fault in publishing the paper.

ChungGKimTHShinHChaeEYiHMoonHKimHJKimJSJungSJOhSBA novel carbamoyloxy arylalkanoyl arylpiperazine compound (SKL-NP) inhibits hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channel currents in rat dorsal root ganglion neuronsKorean J Physiol Pharmacol20121623724122915988"

column12:
provided the original work is properly cited.Resveratrol attenuates lipopolysaccharide-induced dysfunction of blood-brain barrier in endothelial cells via AMPK activation

Retraction notice to:

Korean J Physiol Pharmacol 2016;20(4):325-332

https://doi.org/10.4196/kjpp.2016.20.4.325

It was brought to the Editors-in-Chief's attention that there were significant similarities between this paper and previously published articles. Upon further investigation by Editorial team of Korean J Physiol Pharmacol
column13: this paper might be liable for defamatory publication as substantial overlapped data were found with previously published articles [<xref rid=""B1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref><xref rid=""B2"" ref-type=""bibr"">2</xref>]. Bo Liu
column15: has admitted that the authors asked an agency for writing and submitting the article to <italic>Korean J Physiol Pharmacol</italic>. Bo Liu has admitted this scientific misbehavior and apologized to the Editors and readership of <italic>Korean J Physiol Pharmacol</italic>. However
column16: Min Hu
column17:
another corresponding author has not yet given any clarification.

In accordance with this Journal's policy
column18:
the entire article has been retracted at the request of the Editors. We apologize to all affected parties for the inconveniences caused.

column10:
provided the original work is properly cited.Myosin VI contributes to malignant proliferation of human glioma cells

Retraction notice to:

Korean J Physiol Pharmacol 2016;20(2):139-145

http://dx.doi.org/10.4196/kjpp.2016.20.2.139

The Editors of Korean J Physiol Pharmacol have informed that this article may include the results of experiments that were not performed by the authors. This possibility has been described in an article published in Scientometrics (https://doi.org/10.1007/s11192-016-2209-6) [1]. Although the corresponding author
column12: claimed the experiments were performed by their team and the data collected were true and valid
column14: all authors have admitted that they used inaccurate methods (inaccurate use of shRNA sequences) and inappropriate presentations of the article (plagiarism). All authors have agreed that retraction from the literature is the best corrective action to the scientific community
column15: and apologize to the Editors and readership of <italic>Korean J Physiol Pharmacol</italic>. Given that the scientific integrity of this article has been compromised
column16:
the entire article has been retracted at the request of the authors and the Editors. We apologize to all affected parties for the inconveniences caused.

ByrneJALabbéCStriking similarities between publications from China describing single gene knockdown experiments in human cancer cell linesScientometrics201711014711493"

column4:
provided the original work is properly cited.Small cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder: CT and MR imaging findings

The article ""Small Cell Carcinoma of the Urinary Bladder: CT and MR Imaging Findings"" by Jong Chul Kim
column5: Kie Hwan Kim
column7: published in Korean Journal of Radiology (2003;4:130-135) is for the most part identical to an article by Jong Chul Kim
column8:
entitled ""CT features of bladder small cell carcinoma"" published in Clinical Imaging (2004;28:201-205). The corresponding author (JC Kim) has been contacted and has agreed that the two studies are the same.

"

as Revealed by 1H MR Spectroscopy

The article ""Metabolic Alterations in Parkinson's Disease after Thalamotomy
column6: as Revealed by 1H MR Spectroscopy"" by Hyun-Man Baik
column12: published in Korean Journal of Radiology(2002; 3:180-188) is for the most part identical to an article by Hyun-Man Baik
column13:
entitled ""Proton MR spectroscopic changes in Parkinson's diseases after thalamotomy"" published in European Journal of Radiology (2003;47:179-187). The corresponding author (BY Choe) has been contacted and has agreed that the two studies are the same.

The following article from The Korean Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery
column5: “Effect of pulsatile versus nonpulsatile blood flow on renal tissue perfusion in extracorporeal circulation [<xref rid=""b1-kjtcv-50-411"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>]
column6: ” has been retracted by the Journal Editor-in-chief
column7:
Chang-Young Lim.

This is a duplicate publication of the same research which was published in ASAIO J 2005;51:30–6 as “The effects of pulsatile flow upon renal tissue perfusion during cardiopulmonary bypass: a comparative study of pulsatile and nonpulsatile flow [2].” Authors submitted this article without permission of the Editor of ASAIO J which retains the permission for publishing in another language.

It is a requirement of KJTCVS that same research in another language need a permission from previously submitted Journal Editor.

The following article from The Korean Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery
column5: “Comparison of pulsatile and non-pulsatile extracorporeal circulation on the pattern of coronary artery blood flow [<xref rid=""b1-kjtcv-50-412"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>]
column6: ” has been retracted by the Journal Editor-in-chief
column7:
Chang-Young Lim.

This is a duplicate publication of the same research which was published in Int J Artif Organs 2005;28:609–16 as “The effects of pulsatile versus non-pulsatile extracorporeal circulation on the pattern of coronary artery blood flow during cardiac arrest [2].” Authors submitted this article without permission of the Editor of The International Journal of Artificial Organs which retains the permission for publishing in another language.

It is a requirement of KJTCVS that same research in another language need a permission from previously submitted Journal Editor.

column11:
provided the original work is properly cited.Effects of Estrogen Deprivation on the Rabbit Clitoral Cavernosal Fibrosis

Korean J Urol 2000;41(7):885-891. Korean

The article ""Effects of Estrogen Deprivation on the Rabbit Clitoral Cavernosal Fibrosis"" in Korean Journal of Urology [1] (2000;41:885-91) is retracted at the request of authors. The authors published a more complete version of the article in other language. The corresponding author expressed an apology for any inconvenience this may cause to the editorial staff and readers.

ParkKSRyuSBParkYIAhnKYEffects of estrogen deprivation on the rabbit clitoral cavernosal fibrosisKorean J Urol200041885891"

column15: provided the original work is properly cited.</license-p></license></permissions><related-article related-article-type=""retracted-article"" id=""d36e154"" vol=""29"" page=""7"" xmlns:xlink=""http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"" xlink:href=""23573102"" ext-link-type=""pubmed""><article-title>Specific nephrotoxicity and cardiotoxicity of BT-CAL®
column16: Sigma Anti-bonding Molecule Calcium Carbonate
column19: regret to withdraw our paper entitled ""Specific nephrotoxicity and cardiotoxicity of BT-Cal®
column20: Sigma Anti-bonding Molecule Calcium Carbonate
column22:
which was published in the Laboratory Animal Research 2013; 29(1): 7-11.

The reason why we withdraw the paper is a controversy on the interpretation of the results
column23: because the institution performed the study (Laboratory Animal Research Center
column25: Korea) is not an organization approved for Good Laboratory Practice (GLP)
column26:
and the study was not performed according to the GLP's Standard of Procedures.

Our research group and the manufacturer of the material (BT-Cal®) are planning to perform additional study in a GLP organization. Therefore
column27:
it is expected that we can resubmit a manuscript in the future.

Yun-Bae Kim

D.V.M.

column5:
provided the original work is properly cited.Role of fine needle aspiration cytology in evaluating mediastinal masses

The following article is being retracted as there was an authorship dispute. One of the authors complained of being uninformed about submission and publication of the article. The article was primarily a thesis work of this author. Other authors were contacted along with their head of department. They claimed that it was a team work but wished to withdraw their names from the list of authors. An expert committee of three eminent chest physicians was made to help resolve the issue. Committee on publication ethics (COPE) guidelines were also taken into consideration. A new author's list could not be prepared because uninformed author and the thesis guides failed to meet the criteria for authorship. Please see ‘From Editor's Desk’ for details on the issue.

D. K. Pandey
column9:
Z. Jairajpuri. Role of fine needle aspiration cytology in evaluating mediastinal masses. Lung India 2009;26:114-6.

"

Izet Masic

Concerning of un-ethical behaviors of some authors of the papers published in previous issues of the journal “Medical Archives” Editorial Board and me as Editor-in-Chief decided to retract several papers.

We follow COPE Retraction Guidelines (http://publicationethics.org/files/retraction%20guidelines_0.pdf) and publish a separately citation for retracted article.

The first case is:

Ahmed QA
column11:
Heba P. Urinary biomarkers of acute kidney injury in patients with liver cirrhosis. Med Arch. 2014;68(2):132-6. PubMed PMID: 24937940; (RETRACTED)

Changed with the article:

Masic I
column14:
Mulic S. Comparison of the Quality Assessment of the Medical Education by students of Bologna and the Old System of Studying. Med Arch. 2014;68(2):132-6.

http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4272501/

The second case is:

Latifi-Popovci
column15:
H. Association Between Autoantibodies Against Thyroid Stimulating Hormone Receptor and Thyroid Diseases Med Arch. 2014; 68(2): 79-81.(RETRACTED) 10.5455/medarh.2014.68.79-81

Zvizdic Z

The third case is:

Sahin C

column3:
and Neuropeptide Release in Mouse Chromaffin Cells Is Regulated by Myristoylated Alanine-rich C-Kinase Substrate and Myosin II1542013248125112512013

The authors of “Cortical F-Actin
column5: and Neuropeptide Release in Mouse Chromaffin Cells Is Regulated by Myristoylated Alanine-rich C-Kinase Substrate and Myosin II” (Mol Biol Cell [2009] 20
column6:
3142–3154; doi:10.1091/mbc.E09-03-0197) wish to retract the paper.

The retraction arises from a finding by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Office of Research Integrity (2013) that author Bryan W. Doreian engaged in research misconduct by falsifying data in the paper

column1:
Mol Biol CellmbcmbcMol. Bio. CellMolecular Biology of the Cell1059-15241939-4586The American Society for Cell Biology201857712828970RetractionRetraction for Old Yellow Enzyme Protects the Actin Cytoskeleton from Oxidative Stress132010215842842

The authors of “Old Yellow Enzyme Protects the Actin Cytoskeleton from Oxidative Stress” (Mol. Biol. Cell [2004] 15
column2:
4522–4531; published online before print as 10.1091/mbc.E04-06-0445) wish to retract their paper. They have provided the following statement:

It is with great regret that we have decided to retract the above article. The major conclusions of the article are incorrect
column3: as we have discovered that an unlinked background mutation is responsible for the phenotype ascribed to the <italic>oye</italic> deletions. We have identified the allele responsible for the actin phenotype
column4: and it is a recessive loss of function mutation in the gene <italic>ASC1</italic>. It is this mutation in <italic>ASC1</italic> that causes the reported excessive actin assembly
column5: morphology defects
column6: and sensitivity to oxidative stress. Furthermore
column7: neither the cysteine 285 or cysteine 374 to alanine mutations in actin suppress the actin defects caused by the <italic>asc1</italic> allele. The corresponding author
column9:
takes complete responsibility for this error and greatly regrets any inconvenience his error has caused to his colleagues in the field.

"

Mol Biol CellMol. Biol. CellmolbiolcellmbcMol. Bio. CellMolecular Biology of the Cell1059-15241939-4586The American Society for Cell Biology274737594966991E07-10-1055RetractionRetraction for Lectin-deficient Calreticulin Retains Full Functionality as a Chaperone for Class I Histocompatibility Molecules018201627152517251720162413–2423

The authors of “Lectin-deficient Calreticulin Retains Full Functionality as a Chaperone for Class I Histocompatibility Molecules” (Mol. Biol. Cell [2008] 19
column2:
2413–2423; originally published in MBoC In Press as 10.1091/mbc.E07-10-1055) wish to retract their paper. They have provided the following statement:

Our paper reported that two lectin-deficient mutants of calreticulin retained full ability to support the biogenesis of class I histocompatibility molecules and also bound to the same spectrum of newly synthesized glycoproteins as the wild-type chaperone. During recent efforts to extend this work
column3: we were unable to replicate the results. An investigation detected evidence of contaminating wild-type calreticulin in the original mutant cell lines
column4: contamination that occurred by unknown means in the senior author's laboratory. Consequently
column5:
we wish to retract the paper. We continue to work on the nature of the interactions of calreticulin with client glycoproteins and will be publishing thoroughly validated results on this issue in the near future. We offer our most sincere apologies to the scientific community for any difficulties that may have been experienced. All of the authors have agreed to this retraction.

"

SEE RETRACTED PUBLICATION:

The corresponding author submitted this article [1] to Molecular Cancer on an assumption that the manuscript had been lost during its previous transmission to Cancer Biology and Therapy. In fact it had been received by that journal and was published there
column23:
simultaneously [2]. The authors are therefore retracting the version published in this journal based on the fact that it was initially submitted to the other journal first. The author is deeply sorry for any inconvenience this may have caused to the editorial staff and readers.

Following the publication of this article
column6: an investigation conducted internally within our Department has revealed that the data published in Fig. 5a are not reproducible. Consequently
column7: confidence in the conclusions drawn from the reported resultsin the paper has been undermined and
column9:
all authors involved have unanimously agreed to the retraction of this article.

All authors recognize the seriousness of this issue and apologize unreservedly to the editors
column10: reviewers and readers. We are also in the process of examining other studies in the paper. We sincerely regret that this study has been compromised
column11:
and are committed to rapidly correcting the public record and implementing practices to prevent any recurrence of such a situation in the future.

column3:
pathological and genetic characteristics of autosomal dominant inherited dynamin 2 centronuclear myopathy

XINHONG LIU
column5: JIAN GONG
column6:
TAO WANG and CHUANZHU YAN

Mol Med Rep 13: 4273–4278
column7:
2016; DOI: 10.3892/mmr.2016.5047

We wish to retract our article entitled 'Clinical
column8: pathological and genetic characteristics of autosomal dominant inherited dynamin 2 centronuclear myopathy' published in Molecular Medicine Reports 13: 4273-4278
column9: 2016. The article was submitted by the first author
column11: without the prior knowledge of the corresponding author
column13: or the other authors included on the paper. Furthermore
column14: the details of the paper were not discussed by the authors prior to the submission
column15: and all are in agreement that the paper contains data therein (and interpretations thereof) which are either inaccurate or inappropriate. All the authors agree to this retraction
column16:
and we apologize for the inconvenience caused in this regard.

"

Mol Med Rep 14: 5556-5566
column5:
2016; DOI: 10.3892/mmr.2016.5954

We would like to retract our article entitled ‘Regulatory T cells exhibit neuroprotective effect in a mouse model of traumatic brain injury’ published in Molecular Medicine Reports 14: 5556-5566
column7:
we recognize that there was an undeclared conflict of interest on the part of certain of the authors. All the authors agree to this retraction. We sincerely apologize for any inconvenience that might result from the retraction of this article.

"

column5:

Following the publication of this article
column6: we regret to report that we have been unable to reproduce the results presented in the paper in our subsequent studies. At the present time
column7: we have not been able to ascertain the reason behind this. Therefore
column8:
we would like to retract this article from publication. All the named authors agree to this retraction. We regret any inconvenience to the readers that this retraction will cause.

"

column5: Tilburg
column7: LLC 2011</copyright-statement></permissions><related-article related-article-type=""retracted-article"" id=""d30e81"" ext-link-type=""doi"" xlink:href=""10.1007/s11031-011-9216-y""/><custom-meta-group><custom-meta><meta-name>issue-copyright-statement</meta-name><meta-value>© Springer Science+Business Media
column8:
LLC 2012Retraction to: Motiv Emot (2011) 35:165–180 DOI 10.1007/s11031-011-9216-y

The article “Happiness as alchemy: Positive mood leads to self-serving responses to social comparisons” by Camille S. Johnson and Diederik A. Stapel has been retracted from publication at the request of the first author.

We at Motivation and Emotion were informed of the need to retract the article from the scientific literature on October 13
column9: 2011. Our decision to issue this retraction was based on the October 31
column11: report and recommendation from Tilburg University’s Levelt committee
column12:
which found that contributions to the paper by the second author were based on fictitious data or fictitious scientific studies.

The online version of the original article can be found under doi:10.1007/s11031-011-9216-y.

"

column5:
provided the original work is properly cited.Platelet-rich plasma in periodontal defect treatment after extraction of impacted mandibular third molars

In the article “Platelet-rich plasma in periodontal defect treatment after extraction of impacted mandibular third molars” which appeared in page 139-34
column7: Jul-Dec 2012 issue of National Journal of Maxillofacial Surgery[<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref>]
column8: it has been found that the article contains duplicity of text as well as X-Ray images from a previously published article
column10: entitled “Use of autologous platelet-rich plasma (PRP) in periodontal defect treatment after extraction of impacted mandibular third molars”[<xref rid=""ref2"" ref-type=""bibr"">2</xref>] by author Dr. Sammartino
column11:
in Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery. The author has accepted the mistake and has taken full responsibility of the same. The current article is therefore being retracted.

U. S. Pal

Editor-in-Chief
column12:
National Journal of Maxillofacial Surgery (NJMS)

Erratum to: Naunyn-Schmied Arch Pharmacol (2008) 378:203–215

DOI 10.1007/s00210-008-0302-y

It has come to the attention of the journal
column7:
that a review article published last year (Postma et al. 2008) contains several passages which are identical to text published by other authors (Giembycz et al. 2008) without giving reference to the original source of these text blocks. The journal has come to the conclusion that this constitutes plagiarism and hence has decided to retract the paper.

The online version of the original article can be found at http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00210-008-0302-y.

ReferencesGiembyczMAKaurMLeighRNewtonRA holy grail of asthma management: toward understanding how long-acting β2-adrenoceptor agonists enhance the clinical efficacy of inhaled corticosteroidsBr J Pharmacol20081531090110410.1038/sj.bjp.070762718071293PostmaDSKerstjensHAMten HackenNHTInhaled corticosteroids and long-acting beta-agonists in adult asthma: a winning combination in all?Naunyn-Schmiedeberg’s Arch Pharmacol200837820321510.1007/s00210-008-0302-y18500509"

Low-energy extracorporeal shock wave therapy promotes vascular endothelial growth factor expression and improves locomotor recovery after spinal cord injury published in the Journal of Neurosurgery in 2014 (J Neurosurg. 121: 1514–1525

The article entitled
column9: vol. 52 of Nigerian Medical Journal<xref rid=""ref1"" ref-type=""bibr"">1</xref> is being retracted. It has been found that the text used in the article bears close resemblance with a previously published article entitled
column10:
“What Makes a Good Journal Great?”2 by Nancy Girard in AORN Journal (Association of Perioperative Registered Nurses). The Editor-in-Chief of Nigerian Medical Journal has taken full responsibility for the mistake and conveys his sincere apologies to the readership.

Professor Francis A. Uba

Editor-in-Chief

Nigerian Medical Journal

Retraction Note: Nuclear Medicine and Molecular Imaging
column10:
pp 102–109

DOI 10.1007/s13139-010-0027-y

The senior author (J. Lee) and the first author (S. Y. Jeong) have retracted this review article due to misconduct. They have discovered multiple instances of misreferencing and misquotation in the text which raise the concern of potential plagiarism.

The online version of the original article can be found under 10.1007/s13139-010-0027-y.

"
